timeline.bodyText: Does it have to be null here, could we use Collections.emptyList() instead?
timeline.author: vkryachko

replies.bodyText: Both of them works, but Collections.emptyList() is better, since it explicitly indicates the default value of array is []. Great Call!
replies.author: James201311

timeline.bodyText: Will defaults work for missing json values, i.e. if the above json did not contain "i" at all, would foo.i equal 0?
timeline.author: vkryachko

replies.bodyText:
It won't, but we can support it by adding getOrDefault for each get in the CreationContextImpl.
My concern is that: if it missed the whole entry, will it still be considered as valid?
replies.author: James201311

replies.bodyText:
if it missed the whole entry, will it still be considered as valid?

I think so, otherwise it will not be an optional field afaict. That said, I think it makes sense for getInt to return the default value unless the field is marked as required(which I don't think we have a notion for yet), it also makes getInt consistent with get which returns null today
replies.author: vkryachko

replies.bodyText:
Great call!
Also, since CreationContext is the place to have value-related logic, and DataDecoder is the place to have decoding logic.
I will move the default value logic into CreationContext, and DataDecoder will simply link the fieldRef with null value when the input missed the  entry or encountered null value .
replies.author: James201311
